summary: This is an email correspondence from July 28, 2019, describing Jeffrey Epstein's jail conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan following his arrest on sex-trafficking charges. It details his cell conditions, his former cellmate, and the facility's poor conditions, including his placement on suicide watch after being found unconscious.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier arrested on sex-trafficking charges, currently held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, described as sleeping in a windowless cell and having been moved to suicide watch.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.role: Former cellmate, retired police officer, accused murderer
persons.context: Epstein's former cellmate until Tuesday, a retired police officer accused of killing four people in Chester, N.Y. in 2016. Described as friendly with Epstein.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: The lawyer for Nicholas Tartaglione who describes the jail conditions as 'dark and disgusting' and has filed complaints about the facility. He states Tartaglione and Epstein were friendly.

persons.name: Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman
persons.context: Mentioned as a previous high-profile inmate of the Metropolitan Correctional Center, whose lawyers blamed jail conditions for his failing health.

persons.name: Cesar Sayoc
persons.context: Current occupant of the jail who pleaded guilty to sending bombs to prominent Democrats and is awaiting sentencing.

persons.name: Sayfullo Saipov
persons.context: Current occupant of the jail accused of killing eight people by driving a truck onto a Manhattan bike path.

persons.name: Serene Gregg
persons.context: A case worker at the Metropolitan Correctional Center and president of the correction workers' union chapter who confirms there are mice and broken toilets and sinks in the facility.

connections.description: Were cellmates (bunkmates) in the Metropolitan Correctional Center until Tuesday. Described as friendly and frequently speaking with each other.
Bruce Barket is the defense attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione, representing him in his murder case and advocating regarding jail conditions.
Barket, as Tartaglione's lawyer, had knowledge of and commented on the cell conditions shared by Epstein and his client.
Both were high-profile inmates held at the same federal jail, the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on sex-trafficking charges.

events.title: Bail Denial
events.description: A judge rejected Epstein's lawyers' request for house arrest at his $77 million Manhattan townhouse, denying him bail.

events.title: Epstein Found Unconscious
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his cell on a Tuesday morning and was subsequently moved to a suicide-watch unit.

events.title: Tartaglione's Arrest
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione was arrested for killing four people in Chester, N.Y.

events.title: El Chapo Sentencing
events.description: Joaquin 'El Chapo' Guzman was sentenced to life in prison earlier in the month.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (federal jail in downtown Manhattan)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was being held in a windowless 8-by-8-foot cell in a wing of the Manhattan federal jail known as 'the box,' with conditions described as disgusting, including mice, insect infestations, and standing water.
Epstein's cellmate until a few days prior was Nicholas Tartaglione, a retired police officer accused of a quadruple homicide, with whom Epstein was reportedly friendly.
Epstein was moved to a suicide-watch unit after being found unconscious in his cell on the Tuesday morning before this correspondence.
Prosecutors had found 'piles of cash' and dozens of diamonds in a locked safe at Epstein's New York mansion earlier in July 2019.
The Metropolitan Correctional Center has housed other high-profile inmates like Joaquin 'El Chapo' Guzman, and faces ongoing complaints about poor conditions from inmates and their lawyers.
